values.description:
This patch series is the beginning of the removal of some parts of boost from sdformat.  In particular, it gets rid of the use of boost::regex and boost::lexical_cast in Converter.cc.  Along the way, it also adds a number of additional tests to Converter_TEST.cc, in order to test the code paths where these come into play.  Note that there will be additional patches in the future to remove other users of boost in the codebase, so consider this just a start.


* Remove an unnecessary check from Converter::Remove.

* Remove trailing whitespace in 1_5.convert

* Add in tests for the Converter::Remove method.

* Significantly simplify Converter::Remove.

    In particular, it has no reason to use boost:regex to split
    on ::.  It should act a lot more like Add, where it just
    takes a specific element or attribute to remove, and does
    just that.  As an added bonus, we also add the ability to
    remove attributes with this commit.

* Add in a test for Converter::Remove of attributes.

* Remove an unnecessary check.

* Be consistent with curly braces.

    Always put them after a statement that could be compound,
    even if it is not right now.  It reduces noise, and possibly
    bugs, in future patches.

* Add a test with an invalid move element

* Add a test for an invalid move prefix.

* Add in a test for Converter::Move with copy.

* Replace use of boost::algorithm::regex with std::regex.

* Add a test for converting old <gazebo> -> <sdf>

* Remove use of boost lexical_cast.

    We can just use the standard library stod instead.

values.description:
`sdf::convertFile()` and `sdf::convertString()` have a parameter `_toVersion`, but the result is always the latest SDF version. This is because they call an internal method `sdf::readDoc()` after performing a conversion to the target version, and `sdf::readDoc()` always converts a document to the latest version.

This fixes the behavior by adding a parameter `_convert` to `sdf::readDoc()`. If `true` or unspecified the document will be converted to the latest version. If `false`, `sdf::readDoc()` won't do any conversions.

This also adds documentation about the conversion to a few public methods which use `sdf::readDoc()`, and a test which converts from 1.4 to 1.5.
values.title: Fixed sdf::convertFile() and sdf::convertString() always converting to latest SDF version

values.description:
This is a large series of patches to remove more of boost from sdformat.  I'm sorry it is so big; my best advice for reviewing it is to review each of the patches separately, rather than all in one diff.  Alternatively, I can open up smaller pull requests with a subset of the functionality; just let me know.

I've tested this both on Ubuntu 16.04 and Ubuntu 14.04, and it seems happy both of those places.  I don't have a good way to test on Windows, so I'm going to rely on CI to help me out here.

Once this patch set goes in, almost all remaining uses of boost are for boost::filesystem, which will be harder to remove (but which I have a plan for).

* Fix trailing whitespace all over the tree.

    No functional change.

* Add brackets to all control statements.

    This makes the code consistent across the entire
    codebase.  No functional change.

* Fix up style and indentation.

    No functional change, just making the code consistent.

* Rewrite parser_urdf_TEST.cc

    This just makes it look more like the other tests, and gets
    rid of some unnecessary infrastructure.

* Fix parsing of URDF with an empty origin.

    Previously, attempting to parse a URDF file with an empty
    origin attribute of xyz or rpy would lead to a crash (attempting
    to initialize a std::string with a NULL).  The new code detects
    this situation and just adds an origin of 0,0,0,0,0,0 for an
    empty origin.  Tests for this are also added.

* Switch away from using boost::lexical_cast for parser_urdf.

    Instead we use the std::sto{d,i} where appropriate.

* Add in a test for an invalid origin value.

    That is, it is basically one that we can't successfully run std::stod
    on.

* Write a couple of tests for the stod conversions in parser_urdf.cc

    In the first test, we iterate over a map that contains a list
    of elements that we want to test for.  For each element, we
    parse the XML and then check to make sure that all of the
    elements that we expect to be there are actually there.  We
    also check that the final number represented is what we expect.
    The second test just checks that an invalid number throws a
    std::invalid_argument like we expect.

* Get rid of BOOST_ASSERT.

    Instead, make SDF_ASSERT throw an exception.  This is different
    behavior than what BOOST_ASSERT does by default, but it makes
    more sense for a library to throw an exception rather than
    abort the whole program.

* Update the copyright headers on a bunch of files.

* Remove include of unused boost version.hpp header.

* Replace a couple of uses of boost::replace_all with std::replace.

    This works fine since we are just replacing a single character.

* Replace boost::ilexicographical_compare with a std:: version.

    We use std::lexicographical_compare with a custom compare function
    to ensure that we do the compare case-insensitively.

* Use the split function instead of boost::split.

    This gets rid of the last boost user in Converter.cc, so remove
    the include as well.

* Remove a use of boost::trim and open-code it ourselves.

* Replace uses of boost::replace_all with our own home-grown version.

* Make the split function visible to the entire program.

    We are going to be using it in several other places.

* Use sdf::split to replace boost::split.

* Remove winGetEnv.

    The same thing can be accomplished just by calling std::getenv,
    which Windows implements.

* Deal with Windows in a slightly nicer way.

    We can get rid of the #ifdef and the resulting weirdness in
    the function signature just by adding (void)_color inside
    the function body.

* Add in tests for the joint parameters.

* Remove initialJointPosition, stopKp, and stopKd.

    They were never used for anything, so having the code for
    them seems kind of pointless.

* Remove a lexical_cast to string.

* Remove unused functions.

    This gets rid of dead code, and also removes a couple of uses
    of boost from the library.

* Replace a use of boost::replace_first with std:: equivalents.

* Use the trim function in Param.cc

    This removes one more boost call.

* Add in a new test file for the main parser.cc

    Instead we use the std::sto{d,i} where appropriate.

  • Add in a test for an invalid origin value.

    That is, it is basically one that we can't successfully run std::stod on.

  • Write a couple of tests for the stod conversions in parser_urdf.cc

    In the first test, we iterate over a map that contains a list of elements that we want to test for. For each element, we parse the XML and then check to make sure that all of the elements that we expect to be there are actually there. We also check that the final number represented is what we expect. The second test just checks that an invalid number throws a std::invalid_argument like we expect.

  • Get rid of BOOST_ASSERT.

    Instead, make SDF_ASSERT throw an exception. This is different behavior than what BOOST_ASSERT does by default, but it makes more sense for a library to throw an exception rather than abort the whole program.

  • Update the copyright headers on a bunch of files.

  • Remove include of unused boost version.hpp header.

  • Replace a couple of uses of boost::replace_all with std::replace.

    This works fine since we are just replacing a single character.

  • Replace boost::ilexicographical_compare with a std:: version.

    We use std::lexicographical_compare with a custom compare function to ensure that we do the compare case-insensitively.

  • Use the split function instead of boost::split.

    This gets rid of the last boost user in Converter.cc, so remove the include as well.

  • Remove a use of boost::trim and open-code it ourselves.

  • Replace uses of boost::replace_all with our own home-grown version.

  • Make the split function visible to the entire program.

    We are going to be using it in several other places.

  • Use sdf::split to replace boost::split.

  • Remove winGetEnv.

    The same thing can be accomplished just by calling std::getenv, which Windows implements.

  • Deal with Windows in a slightly nicer way.

    We can get rid of the #ifdef and the resulting weirdness in the function signature just by adding (void)_color inside the function body.

  • Add in tests for the joint parameters.

  • Remove initialJointPosition, stopKp, and stopKd.

    They were never used for anything, so having the code for them seems kind of pointless.

  • Remove a lexical_cast to string.

  • Remove unused functions.

    This gets rid of dead code, and also removes a couple of uses of boost from the library.

  • Replace a use of boost::replace_first with std:: equivalents.

  • Use the trim function in Param.cc

    This removes one more boost call.

  • Add in a new test file for the main parser.cc

values.description:
This is the fifth of the pull requests intended to replace an earlier pull request. The purpose of this series of pull requests is to do more removal of boost from sdformat. Each branch builds upon the last one, so we'll end up with a giant octopus merge in the end.  Note that this PR is requesting to be merged into remove-boost-5 so we only see the differences on this branch.  However, the ultimate goal is to get this onto default.

This particular PR does some miscellaneous cleanup in the tree, removing some parts of boost while we are at it.


* Get rid of BOOST_ASSERT.

    Instead, make SDF_ASSERT throw an exception.  This is different
    behavior than what BOOST_ASSERT does by default, but it makes
    more sense for a library to throw an exception rather than
    abort the whole program.

* Remove include of unused boost version.hpp header.

* Remove winGetEnv.

    The same thing can be accomplished just by calling std::getenv,
    which Windows implements.

* Deal with Windows in a slightly nicer way.

    We can get rid of the #ifdef and the resulting weirdness in
    the function signature just by adding (void)_color inside
    the function body.

* Replace uses of boost in SDF.cc with our own versions.

* Use our version of trim in Param.cc
values.title: Remove boost - Misc (PR 5/5)

values.description:
I noticed that it wasn't possible to run test coverage for SDF. Running this:

`cmake .. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=coverage`

Would give this error:

~~~
CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:132 (include):
  include could not find load file:

    /home/louise/code/sdformat/cmake/CodeCoverage.cmake
~~~

So I copied `CodeCoverage.cmake` from ignition math here, and was able to build coverage.

### Coverage

1. Install lcov: `sudo apt-get install lcov`

1. `cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=coverage ../; make`

1. run tests (`make test`, or individual tests)

1. `make coverage`

1. `firefox coverage/index.html`

You'll see a really red report like this:

![lcovsdf.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ak8x4z/images/3595241416-lcovsdf.png)


### Exception copy constructor to fix test segfault

For some reason, `UNIT_Exception_TEST` fails with a segfault on `~Exception` when trying to `delete this->dataPtr`, but only when running test coverage, so it is [not failing on Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat4-xenial-amd64/6/consoleFull).

After some investigation I noticed there were two calls to the destructor. [This](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30309038/why-is-the-destructor-of-an-exception-called-twice) gave the idea of adding a copy constructor, and it turns out that fixed the problem for me.
values.title: Test coverage

values.description:
This adds the tag `<category_bitmask>` to the 1.6 schema adjacent to `<collide_bitmask>`. It solves #143.

I added tests for `HasElement("category_bitmask")`, because it is important for code supporting this feature to use the value of `<collide_bitmask>` to be backwards compatible.

values.description:
Technically, this PR doesn't do anything to directly remove boost.  However, it does fix up a number of problems I encountered while trying to remove boost, so I collected them under the same umbrella.  Note that this should resolve #77 as well.

* Start branch remove-boost-7.

* Minor style cleanup.

* Fix up the provide_feedback test to be correct.

    As mentioned in issue #77, this test is actually not doing
    much at the moment, mostly because the links don't have
    inertia.  However, nobody ever noticed this fact because
    the test itself was too weak.  Take the proposed patch
    from issue #77, apply it, and then fix up the URDF so
    that we actually test the correct thing.

* Fix cfm damping integration test for URDF.

    Must like for provide_feedback, make sure we are actually
    parsing things properly inside the test, and then fix the
    URDF to have inertial for the link so we hit those tests.

* Update force_torque_sensor integration test to test for joints.

    Just add an extra test to ensure we are seeing all of the joints,
    which we happen to be for this test.

* Change a number of EXPECT_TRUE to ASSERT_TRUE in SDF_TEST.cc

    That way the test won't crash if they somehow become untrue.

* Put all of the parse_urdf.cc functions into the sdf namespace.

* Replace all uses of NULL with nullptr.

* Fix up the provide_feedback test to be correct.

    As mentioned in issue #77, this test is actually not doing
    much at the moment, mostly because the links don't have
    inertia.  However, nobody ever noticed this fact because
    the test itself was too weak.  Take the proposed patch
    from issue #77, apply it, and then fix up the URDF so
    that we actually test the correct thing.

* Fix cfm damping integration test for URDF.

    Must like for provide_feedback, make sure we are actually
    parsing things properly inside the test, and then fix the
    URDF to have inertial for the link so we hit those tests.

* Update force_torque_sensor integration test to test for joints.

    Just add an extra test to ensure we are seeing all of the joints,
    which we happen to be for this test.

* Change a number of EXPECT_TRUE to ASSERT_TRUE in SDF_TEST.cc

    That way the test won't crash if they somehow become untrue.

* Put all of the parse_urdf.cc functions into the sdf namespace.

* Replace all uses of NULL with nullptr.
summary.html:
Technically, this PR doesn't do anything to directly remove boost. However, it does fix up a number of problems I encountered while trying to remove boost, so I collected them under the same umbrella. Note that this should resolve #77 as well.

  • Start branch remove-boost-7.

  • Minor style cleanup.

  • Fix up the provide_feedback test to be correct.

    As mentioned in issue #77, this test is actually not doing much at the moment, mostly because the links don't have inertia. However, nobody ever noticed this fact because the test itself was too weak. Take the proposed patch from issue #77, apply it, and then fix up the URDF so that we actually test the correct thing.

  • Fix cfm damping integration test for URDF.

    Must like for provide_feedback, make sure we are actually parsing things properly inside the test, and then fix the URDF to have inertial for the link so we hit those tests.

  • Update force_torque_sensor integration test to test for joints.

    Just add an extra test to ensure we are seeing all of the joints, which we happen to be for this test.

  • Change a number of EXPECT_TRUE to ASSERT_TRUE in SDF_TEST.cc

    That way the test won't crash if they somehow become untrue.

  • Put all of the parse_urdf.cc functions into the sdf namespace.

  • Replace all uses of NULL with nullptr.

values.description:
This PR actually removes the built-in copy of urdfdom from sdformat.  Along the way, it also upgrades it to use urdfdom 1.0, which gets rid of a lot of boost in sdformat.  Note that the CI is going to fail for all of builds, since we need to update the infrastructure to have an external copy of urdfdom after this PR.  This should close out issue #110, at least.

Jose, I put you on this PR mostly to get some advice on how to start building/deploying stuff on the CI so we can get it to work.  Right now it looks like Linux is failing because pkg-config is not installed, OSX is failing because it can't find URDF 1.0, and Windows is failing because it can't find pkg-config.  That last one looks to be a cmake error, the rest are infrastructure problems.


* Start branch remove-boost-8

* Remove built-in copy of urdfdom.

    From now on, we'll use an external version.

* Make sdformat require urdfdom 0.3 or 0.4.

    That is, we remove the code that deals with urdfdom prior to 0.3.
    urdfdom *after* 0.4.2 requires a change in API which we aren't
    quite ready for, so for right now we restrict ourselves between
    0.3 and 0.4.

* Make sdformat require version 1.0 or later of urdfdom.

    This requires removing the boost code from parser_urdf.cc,
    and replacing with the std:: equivalent API that urdfdom 1.0
    exposes.
values.title: Remove boost 8

values.description:
Gazebo supports light insertion since [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2200/process-insertions-on-world-setstate/diff) pull request, but the use case for that pull request only works because we're not using the SDF parser to extract the light insertions from SDF.

Without the change here, trying to use the parser on something like

~~~
<insertions>
  <light .../>
</insertions>
~~~

gives this warning:

~~~
Warning [parser.cc:778] XML Element[light], child of element[insertions] not defined in SDF. Ignoring[light]. You may have an incorrect SDF file, or an sdformat version that doesn't support this element.
~~~
values.title: Support light insertion in state

values.description:
Flexible build can be configured by adding SDFORMAT_NAME_POSTFIX to cmake defines. For example:

   cmake -DSDFORMAT_NAME_POSTFIX=XXX <src>

will generate the sdformat library libsdformatXXX.so.<version> and other associated directory/files with a different name.

Note, I'm not very familiar with making pull requests so please let me know if I should be doing things differently.

Discussion note:

In making these changes I've realised that there are some things about the packaging philosophy behind gazebo and associated libraries (e.g., sdformat, ignition-math) that I don't quite understand and these change how I would want to make the build more flexible.

To set the scene, many software projects allow different versions of the software to be installed on the same system. For example, python 2.X and 3.X. To do this they install to different locations (e.g., /usr/include/python2.7/ and /usr/include/python3.4) and have different filenames (e.g, libpython2.7.so and libpython3.4.so). When they are package for distribution they also have different names (e.g., debian packages python2.7-dev and python3.4-dev).  This all makes sense to me and won't be news to anyone here.

However, when it comes to gazebo and libraries it is packaged in a way that I don't understand. It seems to be packaged almost in flexible/multi-version... but not really. For example, it uses different debian package names for each version (eg., libsdformat3, libsdformat4). Similarly,  the include files are given unique locations based on the version (e.g., /usr/include/sdformat-3.0, /usr/include/sdformat-4.0). Yet the libraries themselves are not given this flexibility and all end up pointing to the same name (e.g., /usr/lib/libsdformat.so). Similarly, extra resource files are installed in a single version manner (e.g., all packages of libsdformat install to same directory: /usr/share/sdformat). The upshot is that different package versions cannot be installed on the same system.

It seems it would be better to follow a similar pattern to projects like python. So assuming that incompatibilities of libraries occur at major versions then:

- package names stay as they currently are: e.g. libsdformat3

- include directories have the major version number: e.g., /usr/include/sdformat3.

- library name includes the major version number: e.g., /usr/lib/libsdformat3.so, and are sym linked to the full version numbers: e.g., libsformat3.so -> libformat3.so.3, and libformat3.so.3.0.0.

- extra resource also include the major version number: e.g., /usr/share/sdformat3.

This is not what I have done in this pull request. But I think would be a more consistent and flexible build strategy that could be adopted throughout gazebo and its associated libraries.
values.title: More flexible build allowing for multi-version installation.

values.description:
The name of this branch is a bit of a misnomer, since this particular patch series doesn't actually remove any boost.  However, it does add tests and cleanup a few things which will be nice to have for my continuing boost removal efforts, so I figured I would open this up separately.

* Doble -> Double

* Remove FindOS.cmake.

    It's output isn't used for anything, as far as I can tell.

* Style cleanup in Param_TEST.cc

* Style cleanup in Element.cc

* Add in additional tests for Element.cc

* Implement Element Has* functions in terms of Get* functions.

    This is just better code reuse.

* Slightly improve performance in GetElement/GetAny.

    Previously, we were calling HasElement() followed directly
    by GetElement(), meaning we were iterating over the list
    of Elements twice.  Instead, just call GetElement(); if it
    returns ElementPtr() (i.e. nullptr), then we know that it
    wasn't found and we can try our other strategies.  This
    mostly matters if we have a large number of Elements, but
    there is no reason to do the work twice.
values.title: Remove boost 10

values.description:
This is a PR to remove more of boost from sdformat.  This PR is mostly concerned with replacing uses of boost::filesystem in the library.

There are 2 potential problems with this PR that I would like to discuss:

1. If you look closely at Filesystem.cc, most of the Windows code is lifted directly from boost/libs/filesystem, then adapted to fit the sdformat style (along with various other fixes).  I'm not sure how the licensing works in this case; how do we proceed here?
1. There are no tests for Filesystem.cc.  The main reason for this is that I am missing portable versions of some primitives I would need to have reliable tests (change directory, remove directory, etc).  Should I spend time porting those primitives from boost, even though we don't use them in the main code?

values.description:
Actually, this branch doesn't remove any boost.  However, it does a bunch of cleanup and fixes to lay the groundwork for my next PR, which will remove the last part of boost::filesystem.

* Use the Filesystem.cc built-in separator function.

    That way, we don't have duplicate code in Filesystem_TEST.cc

* Add in tests for links.

* Make sure create_and_switch_to_temp_dir succeeds.

* Switch to using the ASCII versions of the Windows functions.

    This allows us to get rid of the funky widen and narrow functions.

* Make sure to include array and string in converter.cc

    It uses them both.

* Combine Windows implementations of exists and is_directory.

    They are almost the same anyway.

* Combine implementations of separator() function.

values.description:
This PR finally removes boost::filesystem from sdformat.  Along the way, it also adds additional tests to get our test coverage up to 100% for some files.  The main addition here is the directory iterator in Filesystem.cc, which has a somewhat complicated implementation.

* Start branch remove-boost-16

* Make sure to do no work with an empty splitter.

* Add in tests for Types.cc

* Get more code coverage on the Exception tests.

* Add additional tests to Filesystem_TEST.cc

    This gets us to 100% code coverage in Filesystem.cc

* Implementation of our own directory iterator.

    This allows us to finally remove all of boost::filesystem.
values.title: Remove boost 16

* Get more code coverage on the Exception tests.

* Add additional tests to Filesystem_TEST.cc

    This gets us to 100% code coverage in Filesystem.cc

* Implementation of our own directory iterator.

    This allows us to finally remove all of boost::filesystem.
summary.html:
This PR finally removes boost::filesystem from sdformat. Along the way, it also adds additional tests to get our test coverage up to 100% for some files. The main addition here is the directory iterator in Filesystem.cc, which has a somewhat complicated implementation.

  • Start branch remove-boost-16

  • Make sure to do no work with an empty splitter.

  • Add in tests for Types.cc

  • Get more code coverage on the Exception tests.

  • Add additional tests to Filesystem_TEST.cc

    This gets us to 100% code coverage in Filesystem.cc

  • Implementation of our own directory iterator.

    This allows us to finally remove all of boost::filesystem.

values.description:
This PR is mostly concerned with removing uses of boost::lexical_cast.  After this PR, we no longer use boost::lexical_cast anywhere in the codebase.

The other big change in here is to rearrange Param::SetFromString and Param::Param (constructor) so that they go through the same codepath for setting fields in the object.  That way, we have the same set of bugs (and bug fixes) no matter which way we initialize the object.

values.description: For some reason many coefficients are documented as being in a range of `[0..1]`, when this is not the case. They should be positive, but can be bigger than 1. So I removed the incorrect limit and expanded some documentation about what the friction and slip parameters mean.

values.description:
I noticed that the SDF parser does not read the child elements of a plugin if the plugin is within an include. 3d19ad2 fixes this bug by calling `readXml` for any plugins identified within an include element. While parsing an SDF, most XML child elements are processed (recursively) using `readXml`, with include elements being an exception, which is why I pursued this solution.

3d19ad2 also coincidentally fixes a second bug. Before the proposed changes if a plugin within an include is missing a required attribute ("name" or "filename"), an exception occurs because the parser assumes the plugin has these attributes. With the proposed changes, the parser will exit with an error message as it normally would for an SDF with a missing required field.

I added two integration tests in plugin_include.cc which fail without the fix. The first tests that plugin child elements are read even within an include. The second tests that `readXml` returns false when a plugin within an include is missing the "filename" attribute (instead of raising an exception).
values.title: fixed parser to read plugin child elements within an include
